results.title: The Si-Ro-Set process
results.brief_description: An account of the Si-Ro-Set Process for setting durable creases and pleats in wool fabrics. The commercial application of the Si-Ro-Set solution with hand spray guns and semi-automatic spray units is demonstrated, also the steam pressing of treated garments in a large clothing factory. The film was released in 1958 when the then new process was released to the clothing trade.

results.title: The Shrines and temples of Japan
results.brief_description: Sketchy type travelogue film with some cultural / historical information. Deer in Nara; history in Nara; history of Nara, one-time capital. Nov 15th, parents accompany children of 3, 5, and 7 year to the family shrine. Description of Shinto, recent development in post-war Japan over shots of temples and shrines. Kamalcura - the Daibutsu, Great Buddha, Shrine maidens in red and white. People visiting temples and shrines. Women bringing children, Toyotomui Hideyoshi’s castle at Osara, built in 1583. Miyajima, stone latern and tsorji in the sea. Vintai Bridge in village of Twakmui; traditional style castle ruins near Mt Asmaa. Kyoto - again commentary on state shinto house by militarist rulers in World War II. Performance of Bugaku, ancient court dances in shrine compound outdoors.

results.title: The Shrine of St. Peter
results.brief_description: Looks at the fascinating archaeological riddle of the Shrine of St. Peter, which is set in the midst of a jumble of ancient tombs and later masonry. Dr John Ward-Perkins describes what has been found under the High Altar, and interprets the evidence found at the site.

results.title: The Showman
results.creator_credit: Eltham Films, Patrick Ryan and Tim Burstall
results.brief_description: Sebastian the Fox is a child prodigy on the violin. A greedy showman attempts to exploit his talents by arranging a world concert tour. Sebastian finds a way to terminate the tour and return home. A Peter Scriven puppet; photographed by Giorgio Mangiamele; edited by Alan Harkness and Michael Thornhill; music by George Dreyfus.

results.title: The Show off [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Famous Players-Lasky Corporation and Malcolm St Clair
results.brief_description: A silent comedy featuring the luminescent Louise Brooks in a secondary role, “The Show off” is the story of Aubrey Piper - a self-promoting windbag full of bluff and blunder. A man of half-truths and self-delusion but much humour, he woos a young woman from a working class family, Amy Fisher, much to the chagrin of her parents. Aubrey lies to her about his income and status within the company for which he works as a clerk and Amy’s parents worry that he is falsely building up their daughter’s dreams of wealth. Clara (Louise Brooks), a neighbour and the girlfriend of Amy’s brother Joe, distrusts Aubrey and seeks an opportunity to expose his deception. Aubrey’s talent for dishonesty and offending the authorities lands him in hot water and the ensuing scandal threatens the ownership of the family home. Social mores and manners of the 1920s are delightfully recreated here in an agreeable combination of satire and melodrama. Ford Sterling - the corpulent funny man best known for his work in Keystone cops - is excellent as the delusional Aubrey. Silent film with intertitles in English and musical score. Note this copy is NTSC, please check your equipment.

results.title: The Shout it out alphabet film
results.brief_description: In this film, simple and vivid collage animation brings words to life in a series of playful appenings involving all letters of the alphabet. It is really a film game in which an audience of children tries to see how many “A” words, “B” words, and so on to “Z”, they can discover on the screen. The process of learning the alphabet and understanding the connection between letters, sounds and words becomes a pleasure.

results.title: The Shout
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Jeremy Thomas and Jerzy Skolimowski
results.brief_description: Alan Bates gives an eery performance in this twisted tale of mind control, primitive power and the dark side of the soul. Bates plays a tramp-like figure named Crossley who claims to have spent many years with the Australian Aboriginals learning their ancient magic and claims to have learnt the power to kill with a shout. The film is a tale by Crossley during a cricket match in an insane asylum. The story centres on Crossley’s meeting with a seemingly loving young couple, he (John Hurt) a successful composer and she (Susannah York) a dedicated nurse in a small village. Crossley seduces the wife and in the process gains an ever increasing power over the couple. With a gripping ending that will have you on the edge of your seat, this is an intriguing film which questions the definition of madness.

results.title: The Short game in golf
results.brief_description: Golfer Tommy Armour demonstrates different styles, grips, and techniques in putting, and displays his techniques for making short, accurate shots when approaching the green. Shows how to extricate the ball from a sand trap. Slow motion photography is used in showing the stance and the swing.

results.title: The Shoplifter
results.creator_credit: Highway Safety Foundation and Herbert J. Leder
results.brief_description: Demonstrates how petty thieves work in shops, and how retail staff can best deal with them. Gives many examples of how petty thieves work in shops, their various techniques and the variety of equipment used to steal all types of goods. Explains the many ways in which a retail store and its staff can best deal with shoplifters through layout of a store, the display of goods and the training and alertness of staff.

results.title: The Shop on Main Street = The Shop on the high street = Obchad na korze (NTSC)
results.creator_credit: Filmove Studio Barrandov, Ceskoslovensky Filmexport, Jan Kadar and Elmar Klos
results.brief_description: The film is set during World War II in the ‘independent’ fascist Slovak statelet. It concerns Tono Brtko, a carpenter who is appointed ‘Aryan controller’ of a button shop by his fascist brother-in-law. The shop is owned by the Jewish Frau Lautmann, who is not only elderly, but deaf and short-sighted, and thinks that Tono is her new assistant. Through a mixture of weakness, vacillation and decency, he fails to disabuse her, and a mutually beneficial relationship develops. This is an extraordinarily effective picture of ‘everyday fascism’ in a small community, and although it revolves around a grim and tragic theme, it is played largely as a gentle comedy. Cast includes Ida Kaminska, Jozef Kroner, Hana Slivkova, Frantisek Zvarik. In Czech with English subtitles.
